value.name: Raigad Fort
value.Desc: Raigad Fort was built by Hiraji Indulkar, the chief architect under the orders of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj in the 17th century. This majestic fort is one of the most significant sites in Indian history, especially during the Maratha Empire. It served as the capital of the Maratha kingdom when Shivaji was crowned as the Chhatrapati in 1674, marking the rise of indigenous rule in India after centuries of foreign dominance. The fort remained a symbol of Maratha strength and resilience through various periods, including confrontations with the Mughals and the British. Strategically perched atop the Sahyadri range at 2,700 feet above sea level, Raigad was nearly impregnable, with only one main entrance (Maha Darwaja) and steep cliffs on all sides, making it a perfect defense post and command center. Due to its elevation and location, it also controlled major inland trade routes between the Konkan coast and the Deccan plateau, making it vital for commerce and logistics. The first king of the fort was Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, and the last ruler to hold it before British capture in 1818 was Bajirao II, after which the fort fell under British control.

list.title: Trekking Difficulty
list.value: Moderate to Difficult – involves climbing over 1,700 steps or using the ropeway

list.title: Best Time to Visit
list.value: October to February for pleasant weather and clear views

list.title: Best Spots to Visit on the Fort
value: Takmak Tok (execution point with breathtaking views)

value.name: Devgiri Fort
value.Desc: Devgiri Fort, also known as Daulatabad Fort, was originally built by Bhillama V, a ruler of the Yadava dynasty, in the 12th century. The fort holds immense historical significance, having been the capital of multiple dynasties over centuries including the Yadavas, Delhi Sultanate under Muhammad bin Tughlaq, the Bahmani Sultanate, and later the Mughals. Its strategic location in the Deccan made it a key point of control for those aiming to dominate peninsular India. Surrounded by steep cliffs and protected by a complex defense system including moats, false doors, and a unique zigzag entry, it was nearly impenetrable. Devgiri also lay on important inland trade routes between north and south India, facilitating economic exchanges and taxation. The first known ruler was Bhillama V, and the last significant ruling authority before British dominance was the Nizam of Hyderabad.

list.title: Trekking Difficulty
list.value: Moderate – involves stairs, slopes, and narrow passages

list.title: Best Time to Visit
list.value: November to February for comfortable weather and clear views

list.title: Best Spots to Visit on the Fort

value.name: Rajmachi Fort
value.Desc: Rajmachi Fort, located in the Sahyadri ranges near Lonavala, was built by the Satavahanas around the 2nd century CE and later fortified by Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj in the 17th century. The fort has historical significance as it played a crucial role during the Maratha-Mughal wars and was used as a watchpost to monitor movements through the Bhor Ghat trade route. Its location between the Mumbai-Pune route made it a strategically important fort for surveillance and defense. The fort oversaw one of the key ancient trade routes connecting the Konkan coast with the Deccan Plateau. The first known rulers were the Satavahanas, and the fort later came under British control after being taken from the Marathas.

list.title: Trekking Difficulty
list.value: Easy to Moderate – accessible from Lonavala or Karjat with scenic trails

list.title: Best Time to Visit
list.value: June to February, especially scenic during monsoon

list.title: Best Spots to Visit on the Fort

value.name: Ratangad Fort
value.Desc: Ratangad Fort, located in the Ahmednagar district of Maharashtra, was captured by Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj in the 17th century from local hill tribes. It served as a strategic watchtower fort in the Western Ghats and was part of the northern Maratha defensive line. Historically, it was important for controlling the surrounding regions and served as a lookout over the Bhandardara and nearby trade routes. The fort is naturally fortified and includes unique rock formations, including the iconic 'Nedhe' or 'Eye of the Needle'. It overlooked major commercial routes connecting inland Maharashtra to coastal ports. The first known ruler was a local tribal chief, and Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj was one of the most prominent rulers associated with the fort.

list.title: Trekking Difficulty
list.value: Moderate to Difficult – steep ascents and rock-cut steps

list.title: Best Time to Visit
list.value: October to February for dry and clear trekking conditions

list.title: Best Spots to Visit on the Fort

value.name: Birwadi Fort
value.Desc: Birwadi Fort, located in the Raigad district of Maharashtra, was built by Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj in the 17th century to keep a watch on the Revdanda creek and nearby trade routes. It held tactical importance in guarding the western coastline and acted as a checkpoint to monitor maritime trade and enemy movement. Its elevated position gave it a commanding view over the Konkan belt, enabling quick communication with neighboring forts. Though relatively small, Birwadi helped regulate regional trade and tax collection from coastal commerce. The first and last king associated with this fort was Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, under whose command it was built and managed.

list.title: Trekking Difficulty
list.value: Easy – short and well-defined trail, ideal for beginners

list.title: Best Time to Visit
list.value: October to March for pleasant climate and visibility

list.title: Best Spots to Visit on the Fort
value: Main entrance gate with Maratha architecture
